body:
Damian, I am wondering if you could organize the IPEP in the following manner:
- Provide a table or list that includes an entry for each slideshow metadata attribute:
- Name the attribute, like `slideshow.hide_cell`.
- Provide a list of the values that attribute can have: `[true, false]`.
- Provide a written description of what that attribute controls: is the given cell hidden is slideshow mode?
- Describe what the UI element will be for that attribute: checkbox with label "hide cell"

That will help us to get a quite overview of all of the attributes and how they map onto the UI.

Thanks!

I did add a pseudo-json of the structure. 
There is no hide-cell for now. 

I propose a 
`slideshow.skip_cell: [ true | false | undefined ]` flag.

Also the UI can be refined afterwards, the important is to agree on what are the metadata we **need** in common.
Yes, I agree that the metadata is the most important thing for now.

I see that you have the new section/subsection/fragment as separate boolean options.  But are they not mutually exclusive.  Shouldn't it be something like:

`slideshow.marker = [none, new_slide, new_subslide, new_fragment]`

also, I find "section" to be confusing - I think we should use the word "slide" instead.
I am +1 on the `skip_cell` attribute you propose above.  It could be "hide", but given the sequential nature of a slideshow, I think that "skip" is better.

El 14/12/12 15:36, Brian E. Granger escribió:

> Damian, I am wondering if you could organize the IPEP in the following 
> manner:

I try to do it by night, I am at cell phone now...

> I see that you have the new section/subsection/fragment as separate boolean options. But are they not mutually exclusive. Shouldn't it be something like:
> 
> slideshow.marker = [none, new_slide, new_subslide, new_fragment]

No, they are not, that was what I though at the beginning but I found a case where it wasn't the case. 
I'll rethink on that to find it. 

> also, I find "section" to be confusing - I think we should use the word "slide" instead.

I think that "slide" is slightly confusing as you have to precise wether or not.
- it is vertical or horizontal in revealjs
- section will actually be "jump point" in live mode.

If you really want to have the `slide` checkbox, then you would have : 
- section
- slide
- fragment

El 14/12/12 15:55, Bussonnier Matthias escribió:

> I propose a
> |slideshow.skip_cell: [ true | false | undefined ]| flag.
> 
> I agree...
> 
> Also the UI can be refined afterwards, the important is to agree on 
> what are the metadata we _need_ in common.

I agree more...

El 14/12/12 16:19, Brian E. Granger escribió:

> I see that you have the new section/subsection/fragment as separate 
> boolean options. But are they not mutually exclusive. Shouldn't it be 
> something like:
> 
> |slideshow.marker = [none, new_slide, new_subslide, new_fragment]|
> 
> also, I find "section" to be confusing - I think we should use the 
> word "slide" instead.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub 
> https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/2680#issuecomment-11388582.

OK, I also think that 'slide' is a better word.
Just for the record, 'section' was derived from reveal.js library but it 
can be confusing.
They were names I asked to @Carreau to test the implementation.

El 14/12/12 16:55, Bussonnier Matthias escribió:

> No, they are not, that was what I though at the beginning but I found 
> a case where it wasn't the case.
> I'll rethink on that to find it.

In the implementation I developed, I assumed "none" if the metadata 
dictionary was empty... so I had the none.

> ```
> also, I find "section" to be confusing - I think we should use the
> word "slide" instead.
> ```
> 
> I think that "slide" is slightly confusing as you have to precise 
> wether or not.
> - it is vertical or horizontal in revealjs
> - section will actually be "jump point" in live mode.

what do you mean with "jump point"?

> If you really want to have the |slide| checkbox, then you would have :
> - section
> - slide
> - fragment

It is confusing also to get section, slide and fragment... because 
"slide" gives the idea of higher hierarchy.

For me section is bigger than slide.. but whatever. 

in reveal.js,  zoomed out your slide would look like:

```
[1] [3] [6] [8]
[2] [4] [7]
    [5]
```

1,3,6,8 beeing new beginning of "section". 
In live mode,  you would actually be able to "jump" from 1 to 3 to 6.

It is actually the same with reveal.js but you don't "see" it because of the change of direction.

As for mutually exclusive Section/Slide, I think my reason was that it is really difficult to explain the **why** or **what does** a section vs a subsection, but thinking of it, it is true that section/subsection/fragment should be mutually exclusive.

El 14/12/12 16:55, Bussonnier Matthias escribió:

> ```
> I see that you have the new section/subsection/fragment as
> separate boolean options. But are they not mutually exclusive.
> Shouldn't it be something like:
> 
> slideshow.marker = [none, new_slide, new_subslide, new_fragment]
> ```
> 
> No, they are not, that was what I though at the beginning but I found 
> a case where it wasn't the case.
> I'll rethink on that to find it.

Because of the structure of reveal.js markdown parser, a "new_subslide" 
has to be also a new_slide. So, to resolve the issue when the user tick 
a cell as new_subslide without ticking the "new_slide", I have coded to 
detect this issue and make a new_slide automatically before the 
new_subslide (I have to do this code more generic, I will do it soon).

> Because of the structure of reveal.js markdown parser, a "new_subslide"
> has to be also a new_slide. So, to resolve the issue when the user tick
> a cell as new_subslide without ticking the "new_slide", I have coded to
> detect this issue and make a new_slide automatically before the
> new_subslide (I have to do this code more generic, I will do it soon).

Ok, now I'm lost. 
I'll take photoshop  tomorrow take  a snapshot of a reveal.js presentation and annotate it.

El 14/12/12 17:35, Bussonnier Matthias escribió:

> For me section is bigger than slide.. but whatever.
> 
> in reveal.js, zoomed out your slide would look like:
> 
> |[1] [3] [6] [8]
> [2] [4] [7]
>      [5]
> |

To be rendered OK for reveal:

[1] [3] [6] [8] have to be section|

[2] [5] [7] [8] have to be end of section

but also:

[1] [3] [6] have to be also subsection

[2] [5] [7] have to be also end of subsection

I hope it is clear now... this structure is why sometimes I call 
"nested" to vertical slides...

Maybe, if you see the html source of the slideshow, you will get a 
better interpretation.
Guys, my english is not enough good as I wish... sorry if I can not explain myself clearly.

Matthias, OK let us know if you can think of the cases where new slide, new
subslide and new fragment could be applied to the same cell.  I can't think
of any, but there may be and we want to get this right.

As far as using section or slide:  in all of the major presentation
software I have ever seen "slide" means something very precise: the
fundamental unit of content that is shown on the slide at one time.  How
slides are organized into the overall structure of the talk (using
sections, etc.) is a completely different question.  Ahh, but this
clarifies some of what you were maybe thinking about:  Here is what i
propose:
- new_slide = use on a cell that begins a new units of content that will
  appear on the screen at one time (ignoring transitions within the slide).
- new_second = begins a new group of cells that belong together logically.
  This can only be applied to a cell that also has "new_slide" (sections
  have to begin at the same point as new slides).  In reveal.js sections will
  be vertically oriented groups of slides.
- new_fragment = this one is completely separate right?

> or not.

> - section will actually be "jump point" in live mode.
>

Fragments are units that can be inside slides o new_second (nested) slides.
And yes, it is completely separate...

OK, can you update the IPEP to reflect this?

## 

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

El 14/12/12 18:28, Brian E. Granger escribió:

> OK, can you update the IPEP to reflect this?

I coming home in a few hours... I will update the IPEP when arrive.

I have updated the IPEP.

Here is the new content (I paste it here for continue the discussion).

#### Structure behind the static slideshow

This proposed structure is in accordance with reveal.js structure to easily render as html slideshow.
All the cells, whatever their contents can be metadata-applied. 
- **new_slide** is the fundamental unit of content: you have to use it on a cell that begins new units of content (that will appear on the screen at one time, ignoring transitions within the slides). You can add new cells to this slide, but they can only be marked as **new_fragment** or **none** (see them later).
- **new_section** begins a new group of cells that, logically, belong together. This have to be applied to all the cells of the group, but the first cell also must have **new_slide** applied. In reveal.js, these are vertically oriented groups of slides.
  **Note**: In the current implementation, we can detect if the user did not apply **new_slide** to the first cell and "make" it for him. 
- **new_fragment** are used to highlight individual elements on a slide. Every element with the **new_fragment** will be stepped through before moving on to the next slide. You can applied **new_fragment** to any cell to highlight it.
- When you do not applied any label, we assumed this cell is **none**, so these are the mainly the "content" of the slides and can be part of a **new_slide or **new_section**.

I still find the language here confusing.  Let use new_slide for the first
one, new_section for the second and new_fragment for the third.

You also state that the second of these has to be applied to all cells in
the group.  Is that what you mean?  I think it should only need to be
applied to the *1st! cell in the group.

We should also name things using this_style not This_style.

On Fri, Dec 14, 2012 at 4:52 PM, Damián Avila notifications@github.comwrote:

> I have updated the IPEP.
> 
> Here is the new content (I paste it here for continue the discussion).
> Structure behind the static slideshow
> 
> This proposed structure is in accordance with reveal.js structure to
> easily render as html slideshow.
> All the cells, whatever their contents can be metadata-applied.
> - _New_section_ (alternative name: _new_slide_) is the fundamental
>   unit of content: you have to use it on a cell that begins new units of
>   content (that will appear on the screen at one time, ignoring transitions
>   within the slides). You can add new cells to this slide, but they can only
>   be marked as _New_Fragment_ or _None_ (see them later).
> - _New_subsection_ (alternative name: _new_second_) begins a new group
>   of cells that, logically, belong together. This have to be applied to all
>   the cells of the group, but the first cell also must have _New_section_(
>   _new_slide_ ) applied. In reveal.js, these are vertically oriented
>   groups of slides. _Note_: In the current implementation, we can detect
>   if the user did not apply _New_section_ ( _new_slide_ ) to the first
>   cell and "make" it for him.
> - _New_fragment_ are used to highlight individual elements on a slide.
>   Every element with the _New_fragment_ will be stepped through before
>   moving on to the next slide. You can applied _New_fragment_ to any
>   cell to highlight it.
> - When you do not applied any label, we assumed this cell is _None_,
>   so these are the mainly the "content" of the slides and can be part of a
>   _New_section_ ( _new_slide_ ) or _New_subsection_ ( _new_second_ ).
>   
>   —
>   Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/2680#issuecomment-11397796.

## 

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

El 14/12/12 22:39, Brian E. Granger escribió:

> I still find the language here confusing. Let use new_slide for the first
> one, new_section for the second and new_fragment for the third.
> 
> OK, let use this convention... I will updated the IPEP.
> 
> You also state that the second of these has to be applied to all cells in
> the group. Is that what you mean? I think it should only need to be
> applied to the *1st! cell in the group.

You have to apply it to each cell of the group.
If you only applied to the 1st one, the second, the third, and so on... 
will be None cells, so they will be displayed in the same 1st slide.
Moreover, reveal.js needs to get this "nested atribute" we called now 
"new_section" from each cell to render properly each vertical slide.
So, the metadata.slideshow dict from each cell belonging to the group 
must have a key - value : new_section - True to be part of the group.

> We should also name things using this_style not This_style.
> 
> ## OK.
> 
> Brian E. Granger
> Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
> bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub 
> https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/2680#issuecomment-11398406.

Ok, for everyone to be happy, 

Here is a schematic of a reveal.js slideshow. 
There is 20 `cells` (grey rectangle)
In blue groups, themselves in red groups. 
3 cells are different and also have letters 16a,17b,18c.

![rv jpg](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/335567/14873/23005ba6-46b5-11e2-83ed-57a3912f938f.png)

I think we agree that a red-group appear at once on the screen, and 2 red groups cannot appear at the same time. 

Except for the 16-18 group that appear in 3 step.
- first (16 a) alone.
- user press next
- (17b) appear leading to 16a and 17b beeing shown.
- user press next
- (18c) appear leading to 16a-18c to be shown.

First do we agree on that ?

> First do we agree on that ?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub 
> https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/2680#issuecomment-11403148.

I agree with you... @ellisonbg proposed to name new_slide to the blue, 
new section to the red and the cells 16a,17b,18c would be new_fragments.
We can use this names convention for now (maybe change it later if we 
consider confusing), but I agree in the structure...
I tried to explain this structure in my previous post. Maybe, we can 
modified the IPEP to include it.
BTW, @Carrieau thanks for the image...

Damián.

I thought 
- blue = section
- red = slide

Whatever.
So if we look at this diagram. 
- 1_, 4, 10, 13 would have a *_blue*\* marker, (implying a **red**)
- 6,8,16,19 would have a **red** marker. 
- 16a does not need a **fragment** marker as it is the first cell of a **red** group.
- 17b,18c would need a **fragment** marker to make them appear one by one. 
- any other cell would be 'None' cells.

[_] 1 would have a *_blue*\* marker by default, unless it is **skipped**

What about the following name : 
- 1,4,10,13 would be "Header Slide" or "New Part Slide"
- 6,8,16,19 would be "Slide"
- **fragment** would stay "Fragment"

and actually, "skipped" is exclusive with the reset so the 5 options are 
- None
- Blue
- Red
- Fragment
- Skip

Yes it is ugly...

Yes, I agree that these 5 states are a complete description of the
different values of the slide state. I like the simplicity of this.  As far
as the naming goes...

red = new slide
blue = new slide group | section (I think that heading is not quite the
right word).

Also, can we update the IPEP to reflect this?  Let's describe what each
state means and give an overview of the design and rationale.  At the end
of all of this I want the IPEP to reflect what we actually code.  Also, can
we put the nice header on this IPEP that this IPEP has:

https://github.com/ipython/ipython/wiki/IPEP-5:-Javascript-structure-and-testing

Also, for an IPEP that is accepted, let's make a link in this table to the
PR that implements it.

Cheers,

Brian
